Differentially Private Federated Learning
without Noise Addition: When is it Possible?

Jiang Zhang, Konstantinos Psounis University of Southern California Los Angeles United States
Abstract.

Federated Learning (FL) with Secure Aggregation (SA) has gained significant attention as a privacy preserving framework for training machine learning models while preventing the server from learning information about users’ data from their individual encrypted model updates. Recent research has extended privacy guarantees of FL with SA by bounding the information leakage through the aggregate model over multiple training rounds thanks to leveraging the “noise" from other users’ updates. However, the privacy metric used in that work (mutual information) measures the on-average privacy leakage, without providing any privacy guarantees for worse-case scenarios. To address this, in this work we study the conditions under which FL with SA can provide worst-case differential privacy guarantees. Specifically, we formally identify the necessary condition that SA can provide DP without addition noise. We then prove that when the randomness inside the aggregated model update is Gaussian with non-singular covariance matrix, SA can provide differential privacy guarantees with the level of privacy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon bounded by the reciprocal of the minimum eigenvalue of the covariance matrix. However, we further demonstrate that in practice, these conditions are almost unlikely to hold and hence additional noise added in model updates is still required in order for SA in FL to achieve DP. Lastly, we discuss the potential solution of leveraging inherent randomness inside aggregated model update to reduce the amount of addition noise required for DP guarantee.

††journalyear: 2024††doi: XXXXXXX.XXXXXXX

1. Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has garnered considerable attention in recent years due to its ability for facilitating collaborative training of machine learning models using locally private data from multiple users, eliminating the need for users to share their private local data with a central server (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Kairouz et al., 2019; McMahan et al., 2017a). A standard FL system involves a central server that oversees the training of a global model, which is regularly updated locally by the users over multiple rounds. In each round, the server initially distributes the current global model to the users. Subsequently, the users enhance the global model by training it on their respective private datasets and then transmit their local model updates back to the server. The server then modifies the global model by aggregating the received local model updates from the users and so on.

Although communicating the local model updates avoids sharing of data directly, it has been shown that the updates can be reverse-engineered to leak information about a user’s dataset (Zhu et al., 2019; Geiping et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021).

To prevent information leakage from individual models, Secure Aggregation (SA) protocols have been employed to enable the server to aggregate local model updates from multiple users without having access to any clear model updates. In each training round, users encrypt their local updates before sending them to the server for aggregation, such that the server can only learn the aggregated model, thereby preserving the privacy of individual updates. Recently, the work in (Elkordy et al., 2022) extended the privacy guarantees for secure aggregation to information-theoretic guarantees on the leakage through the aggregate model over multiple training rounds. However, whether noise induced through vanilla secure aggregation (considering other participating users as noise) can provide worst-case differential privacy (DP) (Dwork et al., 2014) guarantees without any novel randomness has remained an open problem as highlighted in (Elkordy et al., 2022).

In this paper, we target an answer to this question by focusing on formal differential privacy (DP) for secure aggregation (see Fig. 1). Specifically, we provide theoretical answers to the following:

Contributions. We demonstrate that one necessary condition for the aggregated model update to provide DP guarantees for individual user’s local dataset is that the space of each individual user’s model update is included in the space of the aggregated model update from all users, see Sections 3.3 and Section 4 for detailed explanation and formal proofs. We further prove that under the special case where the randomness inside the aggregated model update is Gaussian with non-singular covariance matrix, the aggregated model update can provide DP guarantees for individual user’s local dataset without noise additional, where the DP ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is bounded by the reciprocal of the minimal eigenvalue of the covariance matrix of the aggregated model update.

Moreover, we demonstrate that in practice, the conditions for SA to provide DP guarantee is almost unlikely to hold, especially in deep learning implementations where models are over-parameterized. Therefore, additional DP noise is required in order for SA to provide DP guarantee for individual user’s dataset. Lastly, we investigate the possibility of leveraging the inherent randomness inside aggregated model update to reduce the amount of additional noise needed for the same level of DP.

2. Preliminaries

We start off by presenting the standard federated learning framework before introducing secure aggregation and its privacy guarantees, and concluding with key definitions for differential privacy which are of interest to this work.

2.1. Federated learning

In federated learning (see Fig. 1), a set of N𝑁N users collaborate with a central server to learn a machine learning model parameterized by θ∈ℝd𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Each user i𝑖i has its own local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. For simplicity, we assume that the datasets {𝒟i}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑖1𝑁\{\mathcal{D}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N} are equal in size. The optimization problem to collaboratively solve can be formulated as:

(1) θ⋆=arg​minθ⁡L​(θ)=1N​∑i=1NLi​(θ).superscript𝜃⋆argsubscript𝜃𝐿𝜃1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐿𝑖𝜃\displaystyle\theta^{\star}={\rm arg}\min_{\theta}\ L(\theta)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}L_{i}(\theta).

To solve this problem in a distributed manner, the server and users follow an iterative protocol to train the model parameter θ𝜃\theta. In particular, at the t𝑡t-th iteration, the server sends the latest global model θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)} and each user i𝑖i computes an update xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)} for that model, which is then aggregated by the server to create the new global model as follows:

(2) θ(t+1)=θ(t)+1N​∑i=1Nxi(t).superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\theta^{(t+1)}=\theta^{(t)}+\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}x_{i}^{(t)}.

Two common FL protocols for computing the update are FedSGD and FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017b). In the FedSGD protocol, each user samples a set of ℬ(t)superscriptℬ𝑡\mathcal{B}^{(t)} of B𝐵B local samples and computes the update as follows:

(3) xi(t)=−η(t)B​∑b∈ℬ(t)gi​(θ(t),b),superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscript𝜂𝑡𝐵subscript𝑏superscriptℬ𝑡subscript𝑔𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡𝑏\displaystyle x_{i}^{(t)}=-\frac{\eta^{(t)}}{B}\sum_{b\in\mathcal{B}^{(t)}}g_{i}(\theta^{(t)},b),

where gi​(θ(t),b)subscript𝑔𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡𝑏g_{i}(\theta^{(t)},b) is an estimate of gradient ∇Li​(θ(t))∇subscript𝐿𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\nabla L_{i}(\theta^{(t)}), which is calculated by sampling a sample b𝑏b uniformly at random without replacement from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. In FedAvg, each user will use mini-batches in 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} to run multiple SGD steps and then send the model update to the server.

2.2. Secure aggregation guarantees

Secure model aggregation (Aono et al., 2017; Truex et al., 2019; Dong et al., 2020; Xu et al., 2019; Bell et al., 2020; Elkordy and Salman Avestimehr, 2022; So et al., 2021a; Kadhe et al., 2020; Zhao and Sun, 2021; So et al., 2022; Elkordy and Salman Avestimehr, 2022; Mugunthan et al., 2019; So et al., 2021b) is used in conjunction with FL for providing a privacy preserving framework without sacrificing training performance. SA protocols are broadly classified into two main categories based on the encryption technique; homomorphic encryption (Aono et al., 2017; Truex et al., 2019; Dong et al., 2020; Xu et al., 2019), and secure multi-party computing (MPC) (Bell et al., 2020; So et al., 2021a; Kadhe et al., 2020; Zhao and Sun, 2021; So et al., 2022; Elkordy and Salman Avestimehr, 2022; Mugunthan et al., 2019; So et al., 2021b). In SA, the encrypted model update sent by each user i𝑖i, 𝐲i(t)=Enc​(𝐱i(t))subscriptsuperscript𝐲𝑡𝑖Encsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑖\mathbf{y}^{(t)}_{i}=\text{Enc}(\mathbf{x}^{(t)}_{i}) is designed to achieve two conditions: 1) Correct decoding of the aggregated model under users’ dropout; 2) Privacy for the individual local model update of the users from the encrypted model. In the following, we expound upon each of these conditions in a formal manner.

Correct decoding. The encryption mechanism ensures accurate decoding of the aggregated model of the surviving users 𝒱⊂𝒩𝒱𝒩\mathcal{V}\subset\mathcal{N}, even in the event of user dropout during the protocol’s execution. In other words, the server should be able to decode

(4) Dec​(∑i∈𝒱𝐲i(t))=∑i∈𝒱𝐱i(t).Decsubscript𝑖𝒱subscriptsuperscript𝐲𝑡𝑖subscript𝑖𝒱subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑖\text{Dec}\left(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{V}}\mathbf{y}^{(t)}_{i}\right)=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{V}}\mathbf{x}^{(t)}_{i}.

Privacy guarantee. The encryption should guarantee that under the collusion of a subset of users 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} with the server, the encrypted model updates {𝐲i(t)}i∈[N]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐲𝑡𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{\mathbf{y}^{(t)}_{i}\}_{i\in[N]} leak no information about the model updates {𝐱i(t)}i∈[N]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{\mathbf{x}^{(t)}_{i}\}_{i\in[N]} beyond the aggregated model ∑i=1N𝐱i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathbf{x}^{(t)}_{i}. This is formally given as follows

(5) I({𝐲i(t)}i∈[N];{𝐱i(t)}i∈[N]|∑i=1N𝐱i(t),𝐳𝒯)=0,I\left({\{\mathbf{y}}^{(t)}_{i}\}_{i\in[N]};\{\mathbf{x}^{(t)}_{i}\}_{i\in[N]}\middle|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathbf{x}^{(t)}_{i},\mathbf{z}_{\mathcal{T}}\right)=0,

where 𝐳𝒯subscript𝐳𝒯\mathbf{z}_{\mathcal{T}} is the collection of information at the users in 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}. The assumption of having the set of colluding users to be |𝒯|≤N2𝒯𝑁2|\mathcal{T}|\leq\frac{N}{2} is widely used in most of the prior works (e.g., (So et al., 2022, 2021b)).

2.3. Differential privacy

Differential privacy (DP) has emerged as a reliable mechanism for ensuring data privacy in Federated Learning (FL) through the injection of noise (Wei et al., 2020). When using DP, the server aggregate model still retains an added noise component, unlike the SA approach where the server recovers a non-noisy version of the aggregate. By carefully controlling the level of noise introduced through the DP mechanism, a provable privacy guarantee can be achieved for the local data of participating users, even when the local or aggregated models are accessible to adversaries. However, the required noise for achieving high level of privacy may negatively impact the model’s performance. In the following we formally define DP.

Definition 1 (DP (Dwork et al., 2014)).

: A randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} : 𝒳→R→𝒳R\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathrm{R} with domain 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and range RR\mathrm{R} satisfies (ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, δ𝛿\delta)-DP, if for all sets 𝒮⊆R𝒮𝑅\mathcal{S}\subseteq{R} and for any two adjacent databases 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, 𝒟i′subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑖\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i} ∈𝒳absent𝒳\in\mathcal{X}.

(6) P​r​[ℳ​(𝒟i)∈𝒮]≤eϵ​P​r​[ℳ​(𝒟i′)]+δ.𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳsubscript𝒟𝑖𝒮superscript𝑒italic-ϵ𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑖𝛿Pr[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}_{i})\in\mathcal{S}]\leq e^{\epsilon}Pr[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i})]+\delta.

In (6), ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon represents the level of privacy, where smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon means a higher level of privacy the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} can achieve. On the other hand, δ𝛿\delta is a relaxation item which represents the probability of the event that the ratio P​r​[ℳ​(𝒟i)∈𝒮]P​r​[ℳ​(𝒟i′)∈𝒮]𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳsubscript𝒟𝑖𝒮𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑖𝒮\frac{Pr[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}_{i})\in\mathcal{S}]}{Pr[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i})\in\mathcal{S}]} cannot be always bounded by eϵsuperscript𝑒italic-ϵe^{\epsilon} after applying the privacy-preserving mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. Specifically, when δ=0𝛿0\delta=0, we define that the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies pure differential privacy, i.e. ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP. When δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, we define that the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies approximate differential privacy, i.e. (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP. To achieve local differential privacy in FL, Gaussian mechanism is widely adapted (Wei et al., 2020). In particular, in each training round, each user i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] clips its model update c​l​i​p​(𝐱i,C)=C​𝐱im​a​x​(‖𝐱i‖2,C)𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑝subscript𝐱𝑖𝐶𝐶subscript𝐱𝑖𝑚𝑎𝑥subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖2𝐶clip(\mathbf{x}_{i},C)=\frac{C\mathbf{x}_{i}}{max(||\mathbf{x}_{i}||_{2},C)}, where C𝐶C is a clipping threshold used for bounding the model update of each user. Each user then adds a Gaussian noise n𝑛n with a standard deviation inversely proportional to the privacy level ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

Another relaxation of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP is Rényi Differential Privacy (RDP), which is defined based on the Rényi divergence. We first provide the definition of Rényi divergence between two probability distributions as follows:

Definition 2 (Rényi Divergence(Gil et al., 2013)).

For two probability distributions as follows: P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q over a continuous space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, and for any order α>0𝛼0\alpha>0, α≠1𝛼1\alpha\neq 1, the Rényi divergence of order α𝛼\alpha from P𝑃P to Q𝑄Q is defined as:

Dα​(P∥Q)=1α−1​log⁡𝔼x∼Q​[(P​(x)Q​(x))α],subscript𝐷𝛼conditional𝑃𝑄1𝛼1subscript𝔼similar-to𝑥𝑄delimited-[]superscript𝑃𝑥𝑄𝑥𝛼D_{\alpha}(P\|Q)=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\mathbb{E}_{x\sim Q}\left[\left(\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\right)^{\alpha}\right],

where 𝔼x∼Q​[⋅]subscript𝔼similar-to𝑥𝑄delimited-[]⋅\mathbb{E}_{x\sim Q}[\cdot] denotes the expectation with respect to Q𝑄Q. For α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, Dα​(P∥Q)subscript𝐷𝛼conditional𝑃𝑄D_{\alpha}(P\|Q) converges to the KL divergence as α𝛼\alpha approaches 1.

Based on Definition 2, the definition of (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP is given below:

Definition 3 ((α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP(Mironov, 2017)).

A randomized mechanism ℳ:𝒳→𝒴:ℳ→𝒳𝒴\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} satisfies (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP if for any two adjacent inputs x,x′∈𝒳𝑥superscript𝑥′𝒳x,x^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}, the following inequality holds:

(7) Dα​(ℳ​(x)∥ℳ​(x′))≤ϵ,subscript𝐷𝛼conditionalℳ𝑥ℳsuperscript𝑥′italic-ϵD_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}(x)\|\mathcal{M}(x^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon,

where Dα(⋅∥⋅)D_{\alpha}(\cdot\|\cdot) denotes the Rényi divergence of order α𝛼\alpha between two probability distributions.

Compared with (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, RDP provides a more accurate and convenient way to analyze and quantify privacy loss, especially when multiple mechanisms are applied (Mironov, 2017). Moreover, when RDP is satisfied, (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP can also be guaranteed. Lemma 1 below provides a bridge for converting RDP guarantees into (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP guarantees, facilitating the application of differential privacy in various settings.

Lemma 1 (From RDP to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP(Mironov, 2017)).

A mechanism that satisfies (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP also satisfies (ϵ+log⁡(1/δ)α−1,δ)italic-ϵ1𝛿𝛼1𝛿(\epsilon+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\alpha-1},\delta)-DP for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0.

2.4. Threat model for FL with SA

Server. We assume that the FL server can only observe the aggregated model updates from all users without accessing individual model update from any user. We assume that the FL server is honest-but-curious. It is honest in that it will follow the FL and SA protocols without violating them. It is curious since it may be interested in inferring sensitive local dataset of each individual user from the aggregate model updates.
User. We assume that the users are honest, in that they will follow the FL with SA protocol to calculate local model updates using their local dataset and send them to the server. We assume that the users will not send the incorrect model updates to the server.

Privacy goal. Our privacy goal is to achieve record-level DP for each user. This says, if a user changes one record in their local dataset, the server cannot distinguish the new record from the original one, by observing the aggregated model updates across multiple training rounds.

3. Problem Statement

3.1. Motivation

We define the local dataset of user i𝑖i as Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}, the model update from user i𝑖i at step t𝑡t as xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}, and the aggregated model update from all N𝑁N users excluding user i𝑖i as x−i(t)=∑j=1,j≠ij=Nxj(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑗1𝑗𝑖𝑗𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑡x_{-i}^{(t)}=\sum_{j=1,j\neq i}^{j=N}x_{j}^{(t)}. As demonstrated in Figure 2, when SA is used in FL, the server only receives xi(t)+x−i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}+x_{-i}^{(t)} from the aggregator (i.e. the output of the FL+SA system) without knowing xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)} from user i𝑖i. Since each user conducts the data batch sampling when calculating local model update, the aggregated model update xi(t)+x−i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}+x_{-i}^{(t)} can be viewed as a random vector, which can provide some privacy protection to user i𝑖i’s local dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. Moreover, compared with the case where SA is not used and server knows xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}, user i𝑖i may add less or even no additional noise locally by oneself to achieve the same level of privacy, due to the leverage of noise from x−i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{-i}^{(t)}.

Prior work in (Elkordy et al., 2022) uses Mutual Information (MI) (Ash, 2012) as a metric to measure the privacy leakage in federated learning with secure aggregation. The authors have demonstrated that the model update from each user contains random noise, which can offer privacy protection for other users. Hence, as we aggregate more users, the MI privacy leakage of the individual model update from the aggregated model update will decrease, since more random noise is aggregated.

Formally, the authors in (Elkordy et al., 2022) use the MI between Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} and xi(t)+x−i(t)=∑j=1j=Nxj(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑗𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}+x_{-i}^{(t)}=\sum_{j=1}^{j=N}x_{j}^{(t)} as the privacy metric, which is defined as follows:

(8) Ipriv(t)=maxi∈[N]I(Di;∑i=1Nxi(t)|{∑i=1Nxi(k)}k∈[t−1]).I_{\rm priv}^{(t)}=\max_{i\in[N]}I\left(D_{i};\sum_{i=1}^{N}x_{i}^{(t)}\middle|\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{N}x_{i}^{(k)}\right\}_{k\in[t-1]}\right).

For users with identical and independent data distributions, under the assumption that the model update can be composed of independent random variables after whitening, they prove that

(9) Ipriv(t)≤C​d(N−1)​B+d2​log⁡(NN−1),superscriptsubscript𝐼priv𝑡𝐶𝑑𝑁1𝐵𝑑2𝑁𝑁1I_{\rm priv}^{(t)}\leq\frac{C\ d}{(N-1)B}+\frac{d}{2}\log\left(\frac{N}{N-1}\right),

where C𝐶C is a constant, d𝑑d is the model size, and B𝐵B is the mini-batch size at training round t𝑡t in FedSGD. The inequality (9) indicates that MI between the individual model update and the aggregated model update (i.e. the privacy leakage) reduces linearly with the number of users participating in FL.

However, MI only measures the on-average privacy leakage, without providing any privacy guarantees for the worst-case scenarios. Since worst-case privacy guarantees are stronger than on-average privacy guarantees because they guarantee privacy protection even in situations that are less likely to occur, it is important to investigate how much privacy can leak in the worse-case when combining SA with FL.

Formally, we define the probabilistic distribution of aggregated model update xi(t)+x−i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}+x_{-i}^{(t)} at step t𝑡t as ℳ{Di∪D−i,θ(t)}subscriptℳsubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\mathcal{M}_{\{D_{i}\cup D_{-i},\theta^{(t)}\}}, where:

(10) ℳ{Di∪D−i,θ(t)}​(x)=𝙿𝚛​[xi(t)+x−i(t)=x|{Di}i=1i=N,θ(t)],subscriptℳsubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡𝑥𝙿𝚛delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡conditional𝑥superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑖1𝑖𝑁superscript𝜃𝑡\mathcal{M}_{\{D_{i}\cup D_{-i},\theta^{(t)}\}}(x)=\mathtt{Pr}[x_{i}^{(t)}+x_{-i}^{(t)}=x|\{D_{i}\}_{i=1}^{i=N},\theta^{(t)}],

where D−i=⋃j=1,j≠iNDisubscript𝐷𝑖superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑗1𝑗𝑖𝑁subscript𝐷𝑖D_{-i}=\bigcup_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=1,j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{N}D_{i}. Suppose Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} and Di′superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖′D_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} are two instances of user i𝑖i’s local dataset. If there exists α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 and ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, such that for any Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} and Di′superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖′D_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} differing from one data point, the following inequality holds:

(11) Dα(ℳ{Di∪D−i,θ(t)}||ℳ{Di′∪D−i,θ(t)})≤ϵ,D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}_{\{D_{i}\cup D_{-i},\theta^{(t)}\}}||\mathcal{M}_{\{D_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}\cup D_{-i},\theta^{(t)}\}})\leq\epsilon,

then xi(t)+x−i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}+x_{-i}^{(t)} can provide (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP guarantee and hence (ϵ+log⁡(1/δ)α−1,δ)italic-ϵ1𝛿𝛼1𝛿(\epsilon+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\alpha-1},\delta)-DP for user i𝑖i’s dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}.

3.2. Negative result for DP

We start by using the counterexample from (Elkordy et al., 2022) to show that the aggregated model update can not offer DP guarantee. Specifically, Figure 3 (from (Elkordy et al., 2022)) demonstrates a worst-case scenario where the last 1/4 elements of model updates for user 1, 2, 3 (i.e. x1,x2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2x_{1},x_{2} and x3subscript𝑥3x_{3}) are all zeros while the last 1/4 elements of model update from user 4 (i.e. x4subscript𝑥4x_{4}) are non-zero. Under this case, suppose user 4 changes one data point in their local dataset, making x4subscript𝑥4x_{4} become x4′superscriptsubscript𝑥4′x_{4}^{\prime}. Then, an adversary can perfectly distinguish ∑i=1i=3xi+x4superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑖3subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥4\sum_{i=1}^{i=3}x_{i}+x_{4} from ∑i=1i=3xi+x4′superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑖3subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥4′\sum_{i=1}^{i=3}x_{i}+x_{4}^{\prime}. Hence, the aggregated model update can not provide DP guarantee for user 4’s local dataset.

While the privacy leakage in the worst-case scenarios can be significant, as long as the occurrence probability of worst-case scenarios is small, a reasonable on-average privacy guarantee (e.g. measured by MI) can be achieved. This is the key difference between worst-case privacy guarantee and on-average privacy guarantee.

3.3. What we need for DP guarantee

Based on the above counterexample, a natural question is under what conditions the above worst case can be avoided, such that DP can be guarantee. In general, we need the following two conditions to be held:

  1. (1)

    The random noise among the aggregated model update from others users should be independent of the model update of each individual user.

  2. (2)

    The space of each individual user’s model update should be included in the space of the aggregated model update from all the other users.

The first condition is necessary since it stems from the fundamental “context-unaware" requirements in DP (Dwork et al., 2014). The second condition is necessary for having a finite ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Specifically, as demonstrated in inequality (6), for any xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)} and xi(t)′superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑡′x_{i}^{(t)^{\prime}} calculated from Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} and Di′superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖′D_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} differing from one data point, both P​r​[xi(t)+x−i(t)∈X]𝑃𝑟delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑋Pr[x_{i}^{(t)}+x_{-i}^{(t)}\in X] and P​r​[xi(t)′+x−i(t)∈X]𝑃𝑟delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑡′superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑋Pr[x_{i}^{(t)^{\prime}}+x_{-i}^{(t)}\in X] should be non-zero. Otherwise, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon can be infinite. This says, the space of xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)} (i.e. the set consisting of all possible xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}) must be included in the space of x−i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{-i}^{(t)} (i.e. the set consisting of all possible x−i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{-i}^{(t)}).

Motivated by the above statements on general conditions for achieving DP, in the next section we formalize several specific conditions under which we can analytically derive the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon bound of DP in FL with SA.

4. Theoretical Results

In this section, we analyze under what conditions FL with SA can provide DP guarantee when using FedSGD protocol.

4.1. Basic assumption for gradient noise

We start by making the following assumption about FedSGD protocol in our analysis, which has been widely used in FL (Kairouz et al., 2019).

Assumption 1 (Stochastic gradient with sampling noise and clipping).

For example, in traditional SGD, user i𝑖i will randomly and uniformly sample a mini-batch with size B𝐵B from its local dataset to calculate the model update at each step (denoted as IID sampling). In this case, each element in wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} will be a random variable satisfying wi,j∈{0,1B}subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗01𝐵w_{i,j}\in\{0,\frac{1}{B}\} and ∑j=1Dwi,j=1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗1\sum_{j=1}^{D}w_{i,j}=1, This says, for user i𝑖i, we have wi,j=1Bsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗1𝐵w_{i,j}=\frac{1}{B} for exactly B𝐵B indices j𝑗j, and wi,j=0subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗0w_{i,j}=0 for the other D−B𝐷𝐵D-B indices. Depending on the sampling strategy, the distribution of the gradient noise in SGD will be different.

The other assumption in Assumption 1 is that users will clip their gradients, which is widely used in privacy-preserving machine learning, see, for example, (Abadi et al., 2016).

Although (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP may hold for δ>𝙿𝚛​[wi,j≠0]𝛿𝙿𝚛delimited-[]subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗0\delta>\mathtt{Pr}[w_{i,j}\neq 0], 𝙿𝚛​[wi,j≠0]𝙿𝚛delimited-[]subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗0\mathtt{Pr}[w_{i,j}\neq 0] is significantly larger than a meaningful bound for δ𝛿\delta (Dwork et al., 2014).. ∎

Theorem 1 states that a necessary condition for aggregated model update to provide DP guarantee for each user’s local dataset is that any change of one data point in user i𝑖i’s local dataset will not change the span of all individual gradients from all users. Since the aggregated model update belongs to the span of all individual gradients (see Eq. (14)), when the server observes that the aggregated model is from a different span, it can potentially identify or reconstruct the data point which causes this change. Therefore, the worst-case privacy DP guarantee is violated. Recent works (Pasquini et al., 2022) have proposed attacks to elude SA in FL via model inconsistency across clients or model manipulation. Fundamentally, these attacks work by making the model updates from different users fall into different vector space and hence the necessary condition for worst-privacy guarantee in Theorem 1 will be violated, causing privacy leakage.

4.3. Gaussian sampling noise with non-singular covariance matrix

The most common type of sampling noise is IID sampling. Specifically, consider the scenario where each user i𝑖i will randomly and uniformly sample a mini-batch with size B𝐵B from its local dataset to calculate the model update at each step. We define span1B({v1,..,vK})={x1v1+…+xKvK|∀x1,…,xK∈{0,1B}and∑k=1Kxk=1}span^{\frac{1}{B}}\big{(}\{v_{1},..,v_{K}\}\big{)}=\{x_{1}v_{1}+...+x_{K}v_{K}|\forall~{}x_{1},...,x_{K}\in\{0,\frac{1}{B}\}~{}and~{}\sum_{k=1}^{K}x_{k}=1\}. Since in practice, each user has a limited amount of data points in their local dataset, the aggregated model update xi(t)+x−i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}+x_{-i}^{(t)} will be a random vector which takes value from a finite set (i.e. s​p​a​n1B​(⋃j=1N{gj,k(t)|∀k∈{1,…,D}})𝑠𝑝𝑎superscript𝑛1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑗𝑘𝑡for-all𝑘1…𝐷span^{\frac{1}{B}}\big{(}\bigcup_{j=1}^{N}\{g_{j,k}^{(t)}|\forall~{}k\in\{1,...,D\}\}\big{)}). Without assuming the distribution of user i𝑖i’s dataset, gi,j(t)′superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑗superscript𝑡′g_{i,j}^{(t)^{\prime}} can have infinite amount of possible values. In this case, gi,j(t)′∈s​p​a​n1B​(⋃j=1N{gj,k(t)|∀k∈{1,…,D}})superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑗superscript𝑡′𝑠𝑝𝑎superscript𝑛1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑗𝑘𝑡for-all𝑘1…𝐷g_{i,j}^{(t)^{\prime}}\in span^{\frac{1}{B}}\big{(}\bigcup_{j=1}^{N}\{g_{j,k}^{(t)}|\forall~{}k\in\{1,...,D\}\}\big{)} cannot be guaranteed and hence DP is violated based on Theorem 1.

In the rest of this section, we consider a special type of sampling noise called Gaussian sampling noise, where the weights of individual gradients in model update of each user i𝑖i are Gaussian. We prove that a closed-form ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon bound in DP can be derived for Gaussian sampling noise when the covariance matrix of sampling noise of each user (or the projected covariance matrix) is non-singular.

Proof.

Theorem 19 indicates that the privacy bound ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in FL with SA mainly depends on two main factors: 1) the number of users participating in FL with SA, and 2) the minimal eigenvalues of the model update covariance matrix from each user. As we increase the number of users N𝑁N, ∑i=1Nλi,m​i​n(t)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑡\sum_{i=1}^{N}\lambda_{i,min}^{(t)} will increase and hence the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon will decay. Moreover, when λj,m​i​n(t)superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑗𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑡\lambda_{j,min}^{(t)}, i.e., the minimal eigenvalues of any user j𝑗j’s covariance matrix increase, ∑i=1Nλi,m​i​n(t)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑡\sum_{i=1}^{N}\lambda_{i,min}^{(t)} will also increase and thus ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon will decrease.

However, it is worth noting that Theorem 19 relies on the non-singular covariance matrix assumption (i.e. Assumption 3), which may not easily hold in practice. Especially in applications using deep neural networks, the number of training data points is typically smaller than the number of model parameters (i.e. over-parameterization), and as a result the covariance matrix of the model update will be singular (Du et al., 2018; Allen-Zhu et al., 2019). Motivated by this, we next consider the case where the sampling noise of each user is Gaussian and the gradient covariance matrix is singular.

4.4. Gaussian sampling noise with singular gradient covariance matrix

Before presenting our second theorem, we formally make the following assumption:

Assumption 4 (Non-singular covariance matrix in subspace).

Hence, the aggregated model update x(t)superscript𝑥𝑡x^{(t)} at step t𝑡t can provide (α,ϵi∗(t))𝛼superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖absent𝑡(\alpha,\epsilon_{i}^{*(t)})-RDP and (ϵi∗(t)+log⁡(1/δ)α−1,δ)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖absent𝑡1𝛿𝛼1𝛿(\epsilon_{i}^{*(t)}+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\alpha-1},\delta). ∎

Theorem 31 relies on Assumption 4. It states that for Gaussian gradient noise with singular covariance matrix, in order to provide DP guarantee for user i𝑖i’s local dataset, any difference in aggregated model update caused by the change of one data point in must belong to the same subspace where the randomness in the aggregated model update belongs to. Otherwise, DP will be violated. The counter example in Fig. 3 violates DP since the model update of user 4 fails to satisfy Assumption 4.

Remark 2: Applicability of Assumption 4 in practice. Prior works have demonstrated that the gradient converges to a tiny subspace (Gur-Ari et al., 2018) in the training process of overparameterized neural networks, and mapping gradient into a subspace (e.g. using PCA) can reduce the amount of noise added for the same level of DP (Abadi et al., 2016). Hence, Assumption 4 is a reasonable assumption for overparameterized neural network. However, in order to verify whether Assumption 4 holds, a centralized server is needed to access to each user’s individual gradients and run SVD on them, which breaks the privacy guarantee provided by SA in FL (see Section 2.2). Therefore, in practice, a potential solution is that each user adds additional noise locally to make the covariance matrix non-singular, as discussed in Section 5.

5. Water-filling noise addition (WF-NA) algorithm.

Till now, our theoretical results demonstrate the necessity of additional noise for DP guarantee in FL with SA when the covariance matrix of gradient noise is non-singular. In this section, we explore whether it is possible to leverage the inherent randomness inside aggregated model update to reduce the amount of additional noise required for DP. Specifically, we introduce a novel algorithm called Water-Filling noise addition (WF-NA), which lift the zero eigenvalues (and some small eigenvalues) in the covariance matrix of each user’s gradient noise, in order to guarantee their non-singularity. For simplicity, we refer to this algorithm as WF-NA and describe its details below.

5.1. Algorithm design

The inputs of the WF-NA algorithm for each user i𝑖i include the local dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}, the current global model parameters θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)}, the number of users N𝑁N participating in FL, the clipping value C𝐶C, mini-batch size B𝐵B, the lower bound for minimal eigenvalue budget σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, and the relaxation item δ𝛿\delta. Note that without loss of generality, we assume that the input parameters are the same across users.

First, user i𝑖i utilizes its local dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} to compute the mean gradient and covariance matrix of gradient noise as μi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑡\mu_{i}^{(t)} and Σi(t)superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑖𝑡\Sigma_{i}^{(t)} respectively. We describe this process for FedSGD separately below.

Calculate covariance matrix. For each data point in the local training dataset, user i𝑖i will calculate a gradient from this data point and clip its L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm to make it upper bounded by constant C𝐶C. After obtaining |Di|=Dsubscript𝐷𝑖𝐷|D_{i}|=D clipped gradient vectors, user i𝑖i uses them to calculate the mean μi(t)=1D​∑j=1Dgi,j(t)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑡1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑡\mu_{i}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{j=1}^{D}g_{i,j}^{(t)} and covariance matrix Σi(t)=1B​D​∑j=1Dgi,j(t)​(gi,j(t))TsuperscriptsubscriptΣ𝑖𝑡1𝐵𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑇\Sigma_{i}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{BD}\sum_{j=1}^{D}g_{i,j}^{(t)}(g_{i,j}^{(t)})^{T}.

Run SVD and lower bound the smallest eigenvalue. Next, user i𝑖i will run SVD on its estimate covariance matrix as Σi(t)=Ui(t)​Λi(t)​(Ui(t))TsuperscriptsubscriptΣ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡𝑇\Sigma_{i}^{(t)}=U_{i}^{(t)}\Lambda_{i}^{(t)}(U_{i}^{(t)})^{T}, and clip the eigenvalues in Λi(t)superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑡\Lambda_{i}^{(t)} such that all eigenvalues are lower bounded by σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. Define the updated diagonal matrix with bounded eigenvalues as Λi,+(t)superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑡\Lambda_{i,+}^{(t)}. The revised covariance matrix can be calculated as Σi,+(t)=Ui(t)​Λi,+(t)​(Ui(t))TsuperscriptsubscriptΣ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡𝑇\Sigma_{i,+}^{(t)}=U_{i}^{(t)}\Lambda_{i,+}^{(t)}(U_{i}^{(t)})^{T}. Note that to make the SVD process efficient, we split the d𝑑d-dimension gradient into k𝑘k parts, estimate the covariance matrix for each part, run SVD on these k𝑘k covariance matrices separately, and concatenate them into the final covariance matrix. By running SVD approximately, the time complexity of SVD will be reduced from O​(d3)𝑂superscript𝑑3O(d^{3}) to O​(k​dk3)=O​(d3k2)𝑂𝑘superscript𝑑𝑘3𝑂superscript𝑑3superscript𝑘2O(k\frac{d}{k}^{3})=O(\frac{d^{3}}{k^{2}}) (see similar approaches in (Liu, 2014; Delattre et al., 2012; Tamilmathi and Chithra, 2022)), without affecting the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon bound we have.

Add WF noise. Finally, each user adds Gaussian noise with covariance matrix Δ​Σi(t)=Σi,+(t)−Σi(t)ΔsuperscriptsubscriptΣ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑖𝑡\Delta\Sigma_{i}^{(t)}=\Sigma_{i,+}^{(t)}-\Sigma_{i}^{(t)} into the local model update (i.e. n∼N​(0,Δ​Σi(t))similar-to𝑛𝑁0ΔsuperscriptsubscriptΣ𝑖𝑡n\sim N(0,\Delta\Sigma_{i}^{(t)})).

Following the proof of Theorem 19, we derive:

Hence, the aggregated model update using WF-NA can provide (α,ϵ(t))𝛼superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡(\alpha,\epsilon^{(t)})-RDP and (ϵ(t)+log⁡(1/δ)α−1,δ)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡1𝛿𝛼1𝛿(\epsilon^{(t)}+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\alpha-1},\delta)-DP guarantees to any user i𝑖i’s local dataset. ∎

5.2. Discussion about WF-NA

Intuitive comparison of WF noise with isotropic noise. Figure 4 compares WF noise with isotropic noise, where the x𝑥x-axis represents the index of each eigenvalue and the y𝑦y-axis represents the value of each eigenvalue. The noise contained in the aggregated model update is randomly distributed in the directions of all eigenvectors, and each eigenvalue measures the variance of the noise in each eigenvector direction. When the eigenvalue is larger than σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} (i.e. the amount of noise we need for achieving our privacy target), then the aggregated model update can already provide enough privacy protection, without needing additional noise. Since WF-NA leverages the noise contained in the aggregated model update, by only adding noise to the eigenvector directions where the eigenvalues are smaller than σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, it can add less noise compared with adding isotropic noise, as shown in Figure 4(a) and 4(b).

Comparison of different DP mechanisms. In Table 1, we summarize the DP guarantees of different sampling noise with WF-NA and compare them with the DP guarantees provided by traditional DP mechanisms using isotropic Gaussian noise. It is worth noting that WF-NA itself is not enough to guarantee DP, since it only guarantees that the covariance matrix of gradient noise is non-singular. In addition, it needs to be combined with appropriate sampling noise in order to achieve DP guarantee (e.g. Gaussian sampling noise).

As shown in Table 1, when SGD with IID sampling or Gradient Descent (GD) without gradient sampling is used, the usage of WF-NA cannot provide any DP guarantee, since WF-NA does not guarantee the necessary condition in Theorem 19 (see Section 4.3 for details). Moreover, compared with mechanisms using SGD, the usage of GD and isotropic Gaussian noise injects the least amount of noise into the local model updates, since GD does not introduce any sampling noise caused by gradient sampling, but it does have larger cost than SGD with IID sampling since it uses all data points. Last, when SGD is used, while WF-NA injects less noise compared with the addition of isotropic Gaussian, Gaussian gradient sampling may inject more sampling noise compared with IID gradient sampling. Hence, the total amount of noise added by Gaussian gradient sampling + WF-NA may not be smaller than the total amount of noise added by IID gradient sampling + isotropic Gaussian. In the next subsection, we empirically compare the performance of these mechanisms for the same level of privacy.

5.3. Comparison of DP mechanisms

In this subsection, we consider the tasks of training both a linear model and a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model on MNIST dataset with 50 users. We compare the accuracy of these models when different DP mechanisms are employed during the training process, to verify our theoretical analysis in Section 5.2. Specifically, we compare three mechanisms, described as follows.
SGD-DP: It uses SGD with IID sampling and the addition of isotropic Gaussian (i.e. adding noise in the whole gradient space).
GSGD-DP: It uses SGD with Gaussian sampling and WF-NA (i.e. adding noise to the “unprotected” gradient subspace).
GD-DP: It uses GD without any sampling noise and the addition of isotropic Gaussian (i.e. adding noise in the whole gradient space).

As demonstrated in Figure 5, GSGD-DP has significantly better accuracy than SGD-DP. However, both of them exhibit lower accuracy compared with GD-DP. In terms of training efficiency, SGD-DP is better than GD-DP and GSGD-DP, since it merely requires users to sample a mini-batch of B𝐵B data points and take the average of gradients calculated from these data points as model update. Moreover, GSGD-DP is the least efficient compared to GD-DP and SGD-DP, due to the necessity for WF-NA to run SVD on the covariance matrix of gradient noise (see Section 5 for details). Therefore, we conclude that GD-DP is preferable for maximizing model accuracy without considering training efficiency. Conversely, SGD-DP is recommended when training efficiency is prioritized. Note that when the sampling ratio in SGD (i.e. BD𝐵𝐷\frac{B}{D}) converges to 1, the performance of SGD-DP will also converge to GD-DP. This says, the key difference between SGD-DP and GD-DP is how they trade between training efficiency and model accuracy for the same level of privacy. As indicated in (Cheng et al., 2019), the mini-batch size B𝐵B in SGD-DP can be adjusted to trade between training efficiency and training accuracy. It is noteworthy that while GSGD-DP appears to be impractical due to the requirement to run SVD, investigating how to add minimal noise only to the model update subspace requiring additional noise for a DP guarantee is a compelling research direction. We leave it as future research to explore whether this idea can be practically applied (see Section 6 for details).

6. Discussion and Future Work

Generalization to other FL protocols. While our theoretical results are derived based on FedSGD, they can be generalized to other FL algorithms such as FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017b), by only varying how we generate the model update (i.e. Assumption 1). As an example, in FedAvg, at training round t𝑡t each user conducts multiple local training steps (i.e. a random process) to derive their local model update xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}, which will also be a random vector with some mean and covariance matrix. Therefore, after changing Assumption 1 w.r.t. how we generate xi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{(t)}, Theorem 19-31 can be applied.

Leveraging inherent randomness in model updates. As explored in Section 5, when the inherent randomness in the aggregated model update can be leveraged, the amount of additional noise required for achieving DP guarantee can be reduced, since we only need to add additional noise to the subspace where the randomness in aggregated model updates cannot offer enough privacy protection (i.e. the ‘unprotected” subspace). Despite its potential, several challenges exist in the design of a practical mechanism to leverage the inherent randomness in aggregated model updates to reduce the amount of noise needed for DP.

First, without making any assumptions about the distribution of each individual user’s model update, we are unable to quantify and analyze the distribution of the inherent randomness in the aggregated model update. Hence, the closed-form of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon cannot be derived through theoretical analysis. A potential solution is to approximate the original aggregated model update whose distribution is unknown with a model update satisfying a common distribution. For example, as demonstrated in Section 4, Gaussian gradient sampling noise can be used to make the aggregated model update be Gaussian. While such gradient approximation makes it analytically feasible to derive the bound of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in DP, it actually introduces additional noise into the raw aggregated model update (see Section 5 for details). Therefore, compared with traditional DP mechanisms that add noise directly to the original gradient, whether novel gradient approximation approaches can be developed to improve the privacy-utility trade-offs during DP noise addition deserves further research.

Second, the computational overhead of quantifying and leveraging the inherent randomness in the model update can be large. As demonstrated in Section 4 and Section 5, quantifying the “unprotected” subspace needs SVD, which will significantly increase the runtime overhead in practice. Hence, a practical direction of future work is to explore how to efficiently quantify and use the inherent randomness in the aggregated model update.

Third, to ensure DP guarantee with meaningful ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon for each individual user, users need to clip their gradients such that the distribution shift of the aggregated model update caused by the change of one data point locally can be bounded and hence a meaningful bound for ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon can be guaranteed. On the other hand, if each user clips their individual gradient, the aggregated model update will be bounded and hence cannot be used as unbounded noise with respect to other users. In this case, when applying DP mechanisms with unbounded noise (e.g. Gaussian mechanism, Laplacian mechanism), the bounded inherent randomness in the aggregated model update may not help to reduce the variance of unbounded noise needed for DP guarantee. To address this, potential strategies include the adoption of DP mechanisms that utilize bounded noise distributions (e.g (Holohan et al., 2018; Dagan and Kur, 2022; Liu, 2018)). Another approach involves discretizing the gradient, enabling the addition of bounded discrete noise into the model update (Kairouz et al., 2021).

7. Related work

Secure aggregation (SA) has been introduced to address information leakage from model updates in the context of federated learning (FL). The state-of-the-art uses additive masking to protect the privacy of individual models (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2020; So et al., 2021a; Kadhe et al., 2020; Zhao and Sun, 2021; So et al., 2022, 2021b). SecAg (Bonawitz et al., 2017) was the first practical protocol proposed for FL with secure model aggregation that is resilient for both user failures or dropouts and collusion between users as well as the server, and it is based on pairwise secret keys to be generated between each pair of users for masking the model updates. The cost of constructing and sharing these masks is quite large though, scaling with O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) where N𝑁N corresponds to the number of users. Recent works have managed to reduce the complexity of SecAg to O​(N​log⁡N)𝑂𝑁𝑁O(N\log N), see SecAg+ (Bell et al., 2020) and TruboAggregate (So et al., 2021b). SecAg+ leverages a sparse random graph where each user jointly encodes its model update with only a subset of user, while TruboAggregate leverages both sequential training over groups of rings and lagrange coded computing (Yu et al., 2019). Further overhead reduction has been recently achieved by LightSecAg (So et al., 2022) which uses private MDS codes. The reduction in complexity is based on using one-shot aggregate-mask reconstruction of the surviving users. Other secure aggregation protocols proposed to reduce the computation/communication complexity of SecAg include (Kadhe et al., 2020; Zhao and Sun, 2021).

A different direction to SA to provide privacy in the context of FL is to use differential privacy (DP) by adding some noise to either the data or the model updates. Differential privacy (DP) provides robust mathematical privacy guarantees by ensuring that the individual contribution of a client does not have a significant impact on the final learning result. In a trusted server setting, earlier works such as DP-SGD and DP-FedAvg (Bassily et al., 2014; Abadi et al., 2016; McMahan et al., 2017b) have focused on applying DP centrally in FL, where the server is trusted with individual model updates before implementing the deferentially private mechanism. An alternative approach, local differential privacy (LDP), explores similar guarantees where the server is not to be trusted. In LDP the updates are perturbed at the client-side before it is collected by the server in the clear. The LDP model provides stronger privacy guarantees as it does not require a fully trusted aggregator but it suffers from a poor privacy-utility trade-off. To improve privacy-utility trade-off of LDP, prior works have proposed to use parameter shuffling ((Girgis et al., 2021; Sun et al., 2020)) and different FL protocols ((Noble et al., 2022)). However, these approaches do not consider the usage of SA and hence lead to a significant utility drop (Kairouz et al., 2021).

Although FL systems may still leak information even when SA is utilized, there is an opportunity to apply distributed DP mechanisms which may distributed the added noise among the users thus improving utility, see, for example, recent efforts along these lines (Agarwal et al., 2018; Kairouz et al., 2021; Agarwal et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022; Yang et al., 2023). Specifically, in (Agarwal et al., 2018; Kairouz et al., 2021; Agarwal et al., 2021), differential privacy is achieved by adding novel discrete noise that asymptotically converges to a normal distribution. In (Chen et al., 2022), the authors propose a Poisson Binomial Mechanism for distributed differential privacy that results in an unbiased aggregate update at the server. In (Yang et al., 2023), the authors design a novel transformer layer deployed locally for each user, which effectively reduces the accuracy drop caused by added noise in SA. However, these approaches do not take advantage of the inherent randomness in FL from updates of other participating clients in the system, which is the focus of this work. While there are a few works (Wang et al., 2015; Dong et al., 2022; Carlini et al., 2022) which leverage the inherent randomness from data sampling in centralized learning to protect DP guarantee, they do not quantify to inherent randomness from model updates of other users in FL with SA.

Very recently, the authors in (Elkordy et al., 2022) have used mutual information to show that the inherent randomness from updates from other users may offer some privacy protection in the context of FL with SA. In this work, we focus on whether FL with SA can provide differential privacy guarantees, which is a much stronger privacy guarantee.

8. Conclusions

In this paper, we formally analyze the conditions under which FL with SA can provide DP guarantees without additional noise. We then demonstrate that the impracticability of these conditions, especially for over-parameterized neural networks. Hence, additional noise is necessary to achieve DP guarantee in FL with SA in practice. Future work could explore how to leverage the inherent randomness inside aggregated model update to reduce the amount of additional noise required for DP guarantee.
